DEL. IN FIRST MEET

Black And Blue Team
Final Score 83 2/3-42 1/3

Season Very Successfully
Last Saturday the Johns Hopkins
track team opened its season by
tirimming their opponents from
University of Delaware to the tune
of 83 2/3 to 42 1/3.
The contest took place on the
Homewood track and preceded the
lacrosse game with Yale. There
was a larger attendance than usual
and it is hoped that the students
will continue to support the team.
Hopkins showed that its strength
is in the• sprints, for there it took
6 out of 9 places, of which 3 were
firsts. In this first collegiate meet
Chqssin distinguished himself by
taking first in both the 220 and 440.
He has, therefore, scored 10 points
and has won his letter in his first
meet. Lockard ran gamely and took
second place in the quarter mile despite the fact that he had a spoiled
stomach.
Quirk was high scorer in the
meet, making a total of 12 points.
Kelly also gave a very clean cut
exhibition, coming in first by a large
margin in both the mile and two
mile run.

EDITORIALS
THE ASSEMBLY THREAT
RESHMEN and sophomores are complaining about the action of

Fthe Student Council in threatening to suspend men who fail to
attend the Thursday assemblies. The Student Council is entirely
justified in its action and the only men who are at fault in the whole
transaction have been those very same students who are now complaining so loudly. The Student Council gave the freshmen and
sophomores all the chance they could to attend assemblies voluntarily.
When their lenient policy failed, due to the lack of cooperation on
the part of the members of the lower classes, they took stringent measures as the only policy left open to them.
As long as we have weekly assemblies at Hopkins they must be
well attended. This point has been reiterated so often by the Student
Council and in the columns of this paper that we need not dwell upon
it further. Suffice to say that it is self-evident to those who have the
interests of the reputation of Johns Hopkins at heart. If one grants
them that every speaker must have an audience he must also grant that
are only two ways of securing that audience; men must either attend
willingly, or be forced to attend. The first has failed; the Student
Council is now trying the second.

ing on the fence; on one side lies continued prosperity; on the other,
oblivion. There have been active forces at work this year to push
student activities over the wrong side of the fence. The men who will
be chosen to lead the activities next year will do much to determine
their fate.
There are certain qualities which are necessities for any man who
has the desire to head a college activity. He must have good judgment first of all. He must be able to choose, to accept, to reject. He
must be able to do good work himself. He must be able to organize
his staff. These qualities have been important in the past and are
equally so now, but there is one other characteristic that the heads of
the activities during the year 1930-31 must cultivate and that is .the
ability to make the word on their activity attractive.
Every activity on the Hopkins campus needs men and will need
them more next year. The editors of the publications and the presidents of the clubs must learn to draw forth candidates and to make
those candidates work. They must learn to keep their own activity in
the spotlight in order to re-awaken campus activity. Otherwise activities at Hopkins will fall into disrepute and finally be abandoned.
We advise the present heads of activities to recommend for next
year's offices men who will have the power of attracting freshmen to
their work. We urge the men who shall be elected to cultivate that
power as far as possible.

THE ASSEMBLY THREAT
RESHMEN and sophomores are complaining about the action of

Fthe Student Council in threatening to suspend men who fail to
attend the Thursday assemblies. The Student Council is entirely
justified in its action and the only men who are at fault in the whole
transaction have been those very same students who are now complaining so loudly. The Student Council gave the freshmen and
sophomores all the chance they could to attend assemblies voluntarily.
When their lenient policy failed, due to the lack of cooperation on
the part of the members of the lower classes, they took stringent measures as the only policy left open to them.
As long as we have weekly assemblies at Hopkins they must be
well attended. This point has been reiterated so often by the Student
Council and in the columns of this paper that we need not dwell upon
it further. Suffice to say that it is self-evident to those who have the
interests of the reputation of Johns Hopkins at heart. If one grants
them that every speaker must have an audience he must also grant that
are only two ways of securing that audience; men must either attend
willingly, or be forced to attend. The first has failed; the Student
Council is now trying the second.

ing on the fence; on one side lies continued prosperity; on the other,
oblivion. There have been active forces at work this year to push
student activities over the wrong side of the fence. The men who will
be chosen to lead the activities next year will do much to determine
their fate.
There are certain qualities which are necessities for any man who
has the desire to head a college activity. He must have good judgment first of all. He must be able to choose, to accept, to reject. He
must be able to do good work himself. He must be able to organize
his staff. These qualities have been important in the past and are
equally so now, but there is one other characteristic that the heads of
the activities during the year 1930-31 must cultivate and that is .the
ability to make the word on their activity attractive.
Every activity on the Hopkins campus needs men and will need
them more next year. The editors of the publications and the presidents of the clubs must learn to draw forth candidates and to make
those candidates work. They must learn to keep their own activity in
the spotlight in order to re-awaken campus activity. Otherwise activities at Hopkins will fall into disrepute and finally be abandoned.
We advise the present heads of activities to recommend for next
year's offices men who will have the power of attracting freshmen to
their work. We urge the men who shall be elected to cultivate that
power as far as possible.
